description:
The family patriarch and rich businessman Anthony Westongrove had invited his children to the grand family manor to celebrate his 70th birthday yesterday.

All of the family members arrived at the manor on Friday afternoon, and an extravagant feast was served at 7:00 pm. It promised to be a wonderful evening …

But the birthday celebration came to an unpleasant end when Anthony was rushed to the hospital during the night after falling very ill. Concerned, the entire family stayed at Westongrove Manor and waited for the patriarch to make his return. Today, on Saturday afternoon, Anthony was finally released from the hospital. His unconsciousness turned out to be caused by poisoning. It would appear that one of the guests was after his blood.

Anthony wishes to resolve the matter within the family, which is why everyone who was present has come together again this evening. The question is: What happened yesterday night? Who tried to kill Westongrove?

What is a murder mystery game?

You and your guests slip into the roles of the main suspects of an exciting murder case. The objective of the game is to convict the perpetrator – one of the people sitting with you at the table. This can only be achieved if the players discuss the course of events amongst themselves and compare their experiences of what happened. But be careful: Each character (including you!) has their own dark secrets which they’d be better off keeping to themselves.

You all gather in the wake of the crime and attempt to piece together your memories, with the aim of identifying the perpetrator. In each round, you recall more and more about the circumstances of the crime, as each round deals with a different period of time from the evening the crime was committed. At the end, everyone votes on who should be handed over to the police as the suspect.

Culinario Mortale is a highly interactive game. There are only a few rules, and no pre-prepared dialogue. The focus is on working through the puzzles and discussing the events together.

Alongside a well-structured game manual, each game contains game booklets for between five and eight characters (the number of players for each game can be found on the packaging and here on our website). In the game booklets, each guest will find their personal clues and a description of their role. Each game booklet also includes a brief overview of how the game works. As such, all players can jump right in. The support code included with your Culinario Mortale game will allow you to download the role descriptions in advance from our website in PDF format, and easily send them to your guests via email.

GAME CONTENT:
1 Game Manual, 8 Game Booklets, 1 Incident Booklet (includes of prologue, incidents, solution), 8 name badges, 1 support code

— description from the publisher.

During the ceremonial opening of the New York Grand Hotel the actress Monique Moreau is found dead in her suite. How could the opening celebration end so tragically?

New York, August 1962. Welcome to the city that never sleeps! Everybody who was anybody had come to Manhattan to celebrate the opening of the magnificent Grand Hotel – aspiring politicians, powerful industrialists and beautiful actresses. The largest luxury hotel in the United States was set on redefining the term “five-star”, and was also to be the crown jewel in the empire of Frederic Price. The hotel tycoon was one of the richest men in the country. Since his marriage to the actress Dóra Galor, he was now even better known than before.

The opening speeches were full of praise, and the guests ate and drank copious amounts from the five-course menu. The evening had all the hallmarks of an incredible coming-together of American high society. Once the official part of the event was over, the guests gathered for an exuberant cocktail party at the longest hotel bar in the entire city. But the evening took a tragic turn when the young actress Monique Moreau was found dead in the bathtub of her hotel suite late in the evening. The idea that the young woman, described by the media as the next Dóra Galor, would take her own life is rejected by everyone as incredible.

The police were informed immediately. But it will take the authorities hours to search the entire hotel and secure all the relevant evidence. You have all been requested to stay here in the lobby. Until the police have questioned everybody, you are all on your own in solving the mystery, asking the questions: what happened this evening? How could the opening celebration end so tragically?

What is a murder mystery game?

You and your guests slip into the roles of the main suspects of an exciting murder case. The objective of the game is to convict the perpetrator – one of the people sitting with you at the table. This can only be achieved if the players discuss the course of events amongst themselves and compare their experiences of what happened. But be careful: Each character (including you!) has their own dark secrets which they’d be better off keeping to themselves.

You all gather in the wake of the crime and attempt to piece together your memories, with the aim of identifying the perpetrator. In each round, you recall more and more about the circumstances of the crime, as each round deals with a different period of time from the evening the crime was committed. At the end, everyone votes on who should be handed over to the police as the suspect.

In the game booklets, each guest will find their personal clues and a description of their role. Each game booklet also includes a brief overview of how the game works. As such, all players can jump right in. The support code included with your Culinario Mortale game will allow you to download the role descriptions in advance from our website in PDF format, and easily send them to your guests via email.

GAME CONTENT:
1 Game Manual, 8 Game Booklets, 1 Incident Booklet (includes of prologue, incidents, solution), 8 name badges, 1 support code

— description from the publisher.

Painting Parlay is an educational game meant to teach the world's greatest artists, increase visual literacy for art, and identify elements of style. Players can vote if their opponents are correct, leading to a fun exploration of the arts.

Objective: Be the player or team with the most points after each player’s or team’s five cards have been placed with an artist. For a quick version of Painting Parlay use three cards instead of five.

Set-Up:
Layout the sixteen artists in a four by four grid on the table.
Shuffle the large square art cards and deal 5 cards to each player or team. Be sure not to look at the back of the art cards, as the artist is revealed on the backside of the card. 
Place the small hint cards painting side up, next to the artist grid, players can search the hint deck for a painting. 
Each player or team will take a voting card, and a point card with a clip to track their points.

Rules:
On your turn, you will choose a painting in your hand, examine its style and elements, and compare it to the sixteen artists on the table. 
You will then place your card with whom you think painted this painting, and give a brief reason on why you came to that conclusion.

Hints and Help:
If you are lost and need help you can search the hint deck for your painting, you will get fewer points if you choose correctly, however it will give you its date of creation, and information about the painting or artist. 
Artist Information: At any time on your turn, you can flip one artist card and read a brief summary of their life.
Exchanging Your Painting: Once per game you or your team can switch one of the paintings in your hand with one of the top three paintings of the art card deck. You will take your new painting and discard the painting in your hand.

Once you have chosen who you think painted your painting, the other players will vote, flipping their voting card to a check or an x, on whether they think you guessed correctly or incorrectly. Then flip the art card, and reveal the artist.

If you placed your painting next to the correct artist you will receive a point amount based on whether you used a hint or not. Adjust your scorecard using the sliding clip on the card. If you guessed incorrectly, you receive no points. 
Your turn ends and the next player seeks to match their painting with an artist.

Point Values:
Placed Painting Next to Correct Artist without a Hint: 5 points
Placed Painting Next to Correct Artist with a Hint: 3 points
If you voted correctly what the outcome would be: 2 points

Players continue to place their paintings with an artist until everyone has placed five of their paintings. In the quick version of Painting Parlay, it is only three paintings that are placed with an artist for the game to end.

Look at your scorecard and see who has the most points, that player or team is the winner! Congratulations on your mastery of the world’s most famous masterpieces.

Team Play:
In team mode, this game can accommodate up to eight teams of six players. Each player will receive one painting card and the voting card will be switched between players on a team each turn. Players on the same team can work together to figure out who painted a teammate’s painting and to vote, however it is up to the player whose turn it is to make the final choice. In team mode, players cannot exchange their painting cards for another. The game will end after six paintings have been placed next to an artist from each team.

Become one of the greatest classical composers of all time! You'll use inspiration, seek fortune and hobnob with aristocrats to perform musical masterpieces and achieve your legacy in this engine building game. Get inspired by your rivals' performances to create your own works of genius as the game builds to a crescendo.

Each turn, players choose one of four actions: Seek Inspiration, Seek Fortune, Seek Patronage, or Perform. Inspiration is your primary resource and it comes in three tones - Joy, Passion and Sorrow. Seeking inspiration allows you to gain your resources while all of the other actions will have players spend inspiration to acquire cards.

Complete specific goals to gain Maestro cards and end the game. The player with the most points, wins.

Compose your masterpiece. Secure your legacy.

—description from the designer

A Romanian strategy game for 2-6 players. You need to build as many highways as you can but be careful! Your opponents will sabotage you with unexpected incidents: a broken viaduct, an appeal to the public auction, blocking the works and see if you can repel the attack of opponents with negotiations, allocation of funds, any new builder or with some electoral promises.
It is recommended for 14+ years old players.

How to play:

     Cards with cities will be shuffled and equally distributed for all players. If any cards remain undistributed, you need to put them in a separate stack on the table.
     Cards with vignette will be stacked on the table.
     Cards with sabotage actions will be shuffled and given 10 to every player (if there are 6 players, any of them will be given 8 cards). The rest are placed on the table.


All players start from Bucharest and roll the dice. They need to move their pawn an equal number of points as corresponding on the dice (but he can't step twice on the same point in a turn). If the pawn is placed on a highway point, the player can ask for the related card, by initiating an act of sabotage against the player who owns that card.

What is sabotage:
Sabotage cards have a number of points (e.g.: 1 / 2 / 8 / 0.1 or -3 / -5 etc). A player who wants a card for a highway, needs to put down a sabotage card of negative value (e.g.: -3). The opponent must repel the attack with 1 or more cards with positive value until their sum is greater than the opponent's card (-1 equals +1 or overcome with +2). In case of equality, challenged player can keep his card. Otherwise, if the challenged player overcomes the attack, he can choose a card with cities from the player who initiated the attack. If the challenged player is defeated, the player who initiated the attack receives his requested card.

Vignette cards: 
Can be used only at border crossing points in order to obtain 3 sabotage cards OR to ask for any of highway city cards.
Every route has a specific number of points. The player with most points wins.

20 Dreams is a storytelling card game where each player has a set of 20 emotion cards differentiated by colour. There is another set of white emotion cards in the centre along with picture prompt cards. 
On a player’s turn, they take one emotion card and three picture cards from the centre. They then have to tell a story that uses the picture cards to express the emotion on the white emotion card, which is to be hidden from the other players. The game is themed as if you are telling the group about a dream you had, so the picture cards contain many common dream themes like flying and teeth.
Once the player has told their story involving the 3 picture cards the other players have to guess what emotion was being expressed using their own emotion cards. Those who are incorrect have their corresponding emotion cards taken away (placed in the penalty box), and those that were correct give their cards to the storyteller, the person with the most cards at the end is the winner.

—description from the publisher

A game of pushing your limits, and then some.


Inspired on the cult film This Is Spinal Tap.

Front is pure black. Tribute to fictional Spinal Tap's Black Album, who, in the classic 1984 movie This Is Spinal Tap, were forced to put out their album "Smell the Glove" with an all-black cover after their label refused to release the original, sexually offensive artwork.


Released in the November 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.


GOAL
Be the first player to make the numbers 1 through 11 in order using die rolls and card play.

SETUP
Sort the cards by suit, then give each player A-2-3-4-5-6-7 cards of a suit. This is their Hand. The other cards aren't used.

GAMEPLAY
On your turn, choose to roll one or two dice. You will then use the sum of one or more cards to make one addition or subtraction by combining the sum of the card(s) from your hand with the die roll.

If the exact target number is rolled
You may choose to either:

     Stop rolling and draw one card from the center pool.
     Discard cards to the table face up to combine with your die roll to equal the desired number.


If the target number is not rolled
You must either:

     discard cards to the table face up to make your die roll equal the desired number.
     Choose to end your turn.


After a number is made (via the combination of dice and cards) you will choose to either:

     Continue to the next consecutive number.
     Pass your turn, and draw two cards from the center pool.


If a number cannot be made, you bust. Your turn ends and you draw no cards.

On every subsequent turn, you will begin by choosing 1 card from the common pool and achieve the same target number you failed at your last turn.

END OF GAME
When a player reaches 11, the game will end once all players have taken their turn. The first player to get a value of 11 is the winner, and if tied, the player with the largest sum of values in their hand wins the game.

Time Machine Rocket is a fast, simple and fun card game. It has a great balance between strategy and luck, in addition to the possibility of interfering in the opponents' game.

The theme is inspired by time travel narratives that promote the unexpected encounter of figures from different eras. In short, the idea is to travel in time in search of forming the best team of historical personalities, bringing together figures such as Leonardo da Vinci and Bruce Lee.

In each turn, the player opens a card from the historic decks. She then decides whether to bring that character to her team, or to open a new card. If she opens a Rocket, she advances to the next deck. If she opens a character of the same type that she opened before, she now have to put that character on her team.

The game ends when a player forms a team of 5 characters, of 5 different types (Humanitarian, Military, Creative, Scientist and Explorer). The player sums up the numbers of each character, and the one with most points wins.

—description from the designer

Think fast in Math Rush, a totally thrilling cooperative math game that will make your heart race and your head rev. For three rounds, up to five players must balance strategy and speed, properly sequencing products and exponentials before the timer runs out. Crunch the numbers in a hurry and rack up more points; make an error and miss your goal. Whether you beat your high score or not, it's more fun that you calculated.

Math Rush is a timed, co-operative card game for 1-5 players who race to complete sets of matching cards in the right order.

In Math Rush: Multiplication & Exponents, the cards show products and exponentials that must be played in ascending or descending order, meeting the requirements of the goal cards (such as "Perfect Squares Only").

—description from the designer

In Meta Olympia, you play a Martian colony 'football' club in the not-too-distant future, playing rules that resemble soccer on Earth. The objective of the game is to be the most bad-ass team on the planet by achieving the most combined point.  Player's teams are made up of athlete cards, each offensive, defensive or special abilities.

There are two different stages played over 4 rounds. In the Pre-Season phases, players take turns moving their miniatures forward along modular tiles.  Each tile either helps players improve their team (via recruiting and trading athlete cards) or collecting resources that improve players tactical options.

In the tournament round, players get to to go head-to-head against each other in player vs player matches. Matches are played in 3 rounds where each player uses one athlete card and a die role per round.  Players can also play tactics cards, resources earned from the pre-season phase, to buff or nerf.

Each round determines goals, saves, and potential injuries; with the final match result based on the final score of all 3 rounds.
As players move into the following stages, they have the resources to continually strengthen their team by adding higher-value players.

In tournament in stage 4 is the final championship.  For 2 players, it is a best of 5 matches.  For 3 or more players, it is a round robin. Players go all out to either defend their lead or challenge the leaders.

The final winner is determined by tallying up all the points collected, either through wins, game currency, or special resource cards.

-description from publisher
The Alhambra: Big Box (Second Edition) features all new artwork and includes all 6 expansions and the 2 Queenies amounting to 26 modules.

You are a lead server at the Cryptid Cafe, a Sasquatch-owned restaurant packed with legendary creatures from all over the world. Gather food. Fill orders. Earn the most tips and be crowned, dare we say, the most "legendary" server.

Strategically dispatch your team of Sasquatch servers to the different food stations, gathering the much-needed items to complete your customers' orders.

As you serve the customers they will give you tips based on their satisfaction level. However, with each passing round, the Cryptids get more and more frustrated waiting for their food and will leave smaller tips. Eventually, they’ll leave the restaurant if they are not served fast enough. If that happens, plan on giving the owner some of your tips at the end of the night, he doesn't like to lose customers.

Sounds simple, right? Not so fast, because you’re not the only lead server working tonight. You'll be competing with other players who are trying to serve their customers as well. Spaces are limited. Food stations are breaking. The orders are piling up. Customers are getting angry! It may be wise to share some of your tips with the chef, so you get the food you need first. If all goes well, at the end of the night you'll be the player crowned the most legendary server.

—description from the publisher

A game of hiding, seeking and spooking.

Inspired on the cult film Beetlejuice.


Released in the December 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.


A lovely couple has died, and in a panic to save their home from the living family that's moved in and ruined everything, accidentally unleashed a dangerous ghost promising to rid the house of the living.

SETUP
Choose one player to be the Bio-Exorcist. You are a ghost, and you are trying to scare the living residents of this haunted house out, by moving items spookily around their house.

The other players leave the room to split up 2+ roles: 1 Occultist, 1 Goth, and 0-3 Folks.

While they're gone, the Bio-Exorcist moves as many objects as the number of living players, and hides a spook (represented by a card or a coin) under each one:

     One spook is the postcard, The Handbook for the Recently Deceased.
     One spook (the joker or the largest coin) is Scared to Death.
     The rest of the spooks are the love of the ghost couple.


SPOOKING OBJECTS
An object you spook must be noticeable moved from where it started. To mess with their heads, the Bio-Exorcist may also move 3 more objects without hiding any spooks under them.

It's important that the Bio-Exorcist remembers where they put each card/coin. Record this info, if needed.

Finally, the Bio-Exorcist calls back the living and the game can begin.

PLAYING THE GAME
Each living player may ask one question of the Bio-Exorcist and may peek under one object. They may do this in any order, at any time; there are no turns.

The Bio-Exorcist must answer questions truthfully, but may interpret ambiguous wording as they please. They cannot speak, they answer only with knocks: once for "yes", don't knock for "no", in numbers knocking that many times.

When a living player peeks and finds a spook, they reveal it and earn another question and another peek.

WINNING AND LOSING
Anyone who reveals Scared to Death loses the game immediately.

If the Goth reveals the Handbook for the Recently Deceased, they get to fulfill their dream of becoming a ghost. The Goth and the Bio-Exorcist win.

If the Occultist reveals the Handbook for the Recently Deceased, they exorcise the Bio-Exorcist and the ghost couple. The Occultist and the Folks win.

If all of the love spooks are revealed, the ghost couple  and the living become friends, and get rid of the Bio-Exorcist. All of the living players win.

If no one has any peeks left and there are love spooks unfound, the living have been driven from the house. The Bio-Exorcist wins.

One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'Denmark's Cities'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about the cities of Denmark. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

One of the over 50 implementations of the Box Quiz series, this one with the theme 'History of the World'.

The game consists of a tin box with 50 questions and answers within a category, here about the history of the world. It is a small and simple quiz game, where players simply answer the different questions.

A time-travelling trick taking card game.

Inspired on the cult film Donnie Darko.


Released in the October 2016 Board Game of the Month Club $5+ package.


SETUP
Deal 5 cards to each player face down. Form the Rabbit by dealing 5 cards face up in the center of the table, stacked bottom to top with all cards visible. The face up cards in the Rabbit set the trump suit in the five tricks to be played, in order from top to bottom.

RULES

1. Form timelines. Choose a card from your hand, place it face down in front of you. Then pass the remaining cards to the left, and repeat, placing later cards closer to the Rabbit to form a line extending from yourself, until all cards have been placed, in the order labeled Form Timeline. Do not look at the last card passed to you.

2. Predict the future. At the count of three, bid simultaneously on the number of tricks the player to your left will win.

3. Resolve tricks. In the order labeled Resolve Tricks, everyone reveals the next card in their timelines, and evaluate the trick. In the first trick, the player to the left of the dealer leads, and thereafter the player who won the previous trick leads. A trick is won by the highest card matching the lead player's suit, unless cards matching the suit of the current Rabbit card have been played, in which case the highest card in the Rabbit suit wins.

4. Score points. After all 5 tricks have been played, score points: 1 point for each won trick, and an additional 2 points for having correctly bid the number of tricks won by the player to your left.

TIME TRAVEL
After scoring once, the game "goes back in time". Pick up the last card in your timeline, labeled Time Travel. Then, moving towards the Rabbit, pick up 1 card at a time and place it on top of the others in your hand. Keep the cards face up when collecting and passing. Finally, starting with yourself, take the top card and pass the remaining cards to your right. Repeat until each player has 5 cards, the same cards they had at the beginning of the game.

WINNING
Add up scores from the two rounds to determine a winner.

A word game that can be played alone or with friends.

Players work together for a high score by forming tough words, but they cannot communicate during their turns. On each player's turn they will say a word outloud that includes at least 2 different letters that are currently shown on the board (and not covered).

Then they'll choose one of the letters in that word and place a penny on it, heads side up. If the word includes 3 different letters fromm the board, then the penny is placed tails side up.

The game ends immediately when one letter remains or a player cannot say a word that uses two letters. The last word cannot include a red letter.

SCORE: The blue outside spaces are worth one point and the purple inside spaces are worth two points. Any spaces with tails are worth one extra point.

Just beyond the towering vines lies an ancient pathway into the unknown. Push back the thorn-riddled stocks to discover a clandestine garden, blooming with mysterious vigor. Vivid colors mark the way to intricate tiles zigging and zagging through the green. Within the flowers lies the key to greater meaning. An explanation for all things unknown...

In Umbra Via, players compete to control and complete the most cunning paths. Reach into your bag to select wooden flowers, then place them on your secret board in the order of the paths you want most. But when players reveal their choices, things get delightfully tricky. Experience the magic of Umbra Via and find out why this award-winning design belongs on any table.

In more detail, at the start of each round four tiles are revealed from the deck, with each tile showing part of a path, e.g., a straight line, a curve, or a T. Players secretly draw three cubes from their bag and place them on spaces on their personal board corresponding to these tiles. They all reveal their choices, move their cubes to the chosen tiles, then secretly place three more cubes, then move those cubes to the tiles. Whichever tile ends up with the fewest cubes on it is placed in the 4x4 grid first, maintaining the same orientation, by the player who bid the most cubes on that tile. (Some cubes in your bag are worth two cubes during the bidding phase, but are then removed from the tile and returned to your bag prior to placement.) Then the next tile is placed on the grid, and so on.

When you place a tile, if all the "open" ends of that path are cut off — whether by the edge of the board or other tiles — you count how many cubes each player has on the path. The player with the most placed cubes retrieves "double-bidding" cubes from the reserve equal to the number of tiles in the path, adding these cubes and all other cubes to their bag. The player with the secondmost cubes on the path retrieves half this many "double-bidding" cubes, and so on. After removing and returning all the cubes on this path, remove the tiles from the grid, placing them in a discard pile.

As soon as a player has retrieved all of their "double-bidding" cubes from the reserve, they win!

In this game the players (2/4) represent the Italian political alignments. They will compete in a election campaign to became the winner of the election day and go to rule the country.

The game is divided in two parts, the first part with the election campaign and the second part with 5 years (turns) of government life.

Every alignments have 1.000.000 euro (53 coin tokens in different coined cuts) to spend in the election campaign between the 20 Italian regions. Closed the first part with the established roles (government and opposition),it starts the second part, government life.

There are 5 turns, every turn has 4 stages, economic government maneuver,government life, year-end balance sheet and reset, except the first turn that has 1 extra stage (government agenda). During the second stage, the players will play a total of 12 event cards, one for every month and 4 decree laws will vote at the senate. The goal for the Government is to conclude the legislative mandate, the goal for the opposition is to bring down the government before the legislative mandate let it be concluded.

-description from designer

Za kralja i otadÅ¾binu: Äeneral DraÅ¾a ("For King and Country: General Mihailovich") is set in WWII Yugoslavia occupied by the Axis and their satellites, while the resistance is divided.

The basic game is for 2 players, one player acting as the leader of the Yugoslav (Royal) Army (Mihailovich), while the other leads the Communist Partisans (Tito). The advanced game is for 1-2 players - the player leading Mihailovich can play solo.

The main goal of both guerrillas is to fight the Axis and the opposing guerrillas, retain the support of the people and Allies, and control Yugoslavia after the war.

If you are Mihailovich in the advanced game, your additional (extremely difficult) goal is also to minimize Serb civilian casualties.

Slumpen (Coincidence) is the main character in a Swedish TV program for children from the 80s.

The game is simple and very similar to the game Snail's Pace Race. In your turn, you roll the color dice and move the figure whose color corresponds to the roll one step. If you roll and the side with all the colors comes up, you can move any game piece to the nearest color square with the same color as the game piece. Whoever first manages to move one of the game piece to the finish line wins.

Guess right about how much money the other players want to do stunts of varying degrees of scaryness. You are the winner if you are the one who can best predict what your friends are willing to do!

The active player takes a stunt card and reads aloud "Which is the smallest amount of money I would ..." and then the text on the card. Then the active player chooses one of his player cards, which has the values for free, for a thousand kronor, for ten thousand kronor, for a hundred thousand kronor, for a million kronor or not for a million! Other players should now try to figure out the active player's choice. Everyone who matches the active player's choice will receive a 100,000 note. Then it goes on to the next player who reads a stunt card. The first player to collect 1,000,000 wins.

An example of a question might be "... for a month tell every single person I meet that I'm not from this world?"

Bilda regering ("Forming a government") is a game that wants to show how the work is done in the government and parliament in a country where the people can have their say in free elections. Wants to provide a basic understanding of how democracy works.

Each player represents each of the parties that existed in the Swedish parliament during the seventies. In turn, you roll a dice and walk so many steps along the playing field. After that, you do what is written on the box you have landed on. It may be, for example, that you may place a proposal in one of the Riksdag's committees and mark the relevant sectors of society with a marker, or move the proposals from the committees to the Riksdag's chamber pending a vote that occurs when someone lands on a box marked with a vote.

As soon as there are markers in all sectors of society on the opposition part of the playing field, a government can be formed. The party that has the most markers in the sectors of society is given the task of trying to form a majority government or minority government together with another party.

Every three years there is an election to the Riksdag (represented by the fastest player having reached the start after three laps). Which may lead to the formation of a new government depending on the conditions of the markers in the sectors of society.

Before the game, the player decides how the winner will be chosen. It can, for example, be the party that succeeds in pushing through the most proposals in the Riksdag, the party that after a certain number of rounds has the most points or the party that has managed to stay in government for the longest time.

Patch: The Card Game is a tool to let players explore their modular synthesis skills in a fun way.

The game can be played solo or as a multiplayer game.

Separate and shuffle the Abstraction cards into their own pile.  Shuffle the Progression a Abstraction cards into another pile. Draw at least one Abstraction card and start patching, following the rule set by that card. The Abstraction card should stay in play for reference.

At some interval (eg. every 5min), draw a card from the Progression/Disruption pile and do the actions described on the card before placing it in a discard pile.  Repeat this as many times as you like until you feel the patch is finished.  If you run out of Progression/Disruptions cards, shuffle the discard pile as your new draw pile.

Patch Battle Royale, or “PBR” for short, is like the multiplayer version of the Basic Game.  2-4 participants is recommended with a single Patch TCG deck.  Multiple decks can be combined for more than 4 players, or if desired for 3 or 4 players to have more cards in their hand.

Start with the Basic Game setup and draw one Abstraction card which will be shared for all players.

Each player then gets dealt 5 cards from the Progression/Disruption pile (4 cards if there are 4 players).
Everyone starts patching.  At some interval, (eg. every 5min), each participant gets to play a single card from their hand.  They can play this card on themselves, in which case they do the action.  Or, they can play it against another player, in which case that player has to do the action.

The battle concludes 5 minutes after the last cards are played. Patches are auditioned/performed/etc and compared.  “Coolest” patch wins.

Blade Rondo: Frost Veil is a stand-alone expansion for Blade Rondo. It can be played on its own, using the same rules as the original game, or can be combined with the base game as an expansion.

Rules and cards for playing solo are also included, including some new Solo-play mechanics unique to this expansion.

Blade Rondo is a minimalist, non-collectable card game for two players where each player selects just seven cards per match.

This expansion adds a mechanic for Freezing cards, allowing their effect to be delayed to subsequent turns to add additional strategic depth.

A board game for 2 to 6 players where you are one of a crew of astronauts who must collect the Intergalactic Space Biscuit and escape from the Intergalactic Space Pickles to win. Along the way, you must collect colored keys to open colored doors and avoid the Pickles who will try to interfere with your progress. 
The game is a race to the finish that utilizes both dice and a spinner. Collect character cards to purchase the colored keys, teleport around your current Sector, and make your way deeper into the center of the ship to gain the ultimate McGuffin: the Intergalactic Space Biscuit!
Want a longer game? Make your way back out of the ship and to the escape pod to freedom!
Feeling competitive? Bonus spins give you an advantage over other players by taking away their hard-earned cards and keys or even swapping the door colors to foil their strategy!

—description from the designer

Players take the part of oil investors, buying oilfields, oil companies, and insurance. Drill for oil, administer finds and evaluate what pays, based on the oil price in force.

Roll dice and move that number of spaces around the board. When you pass start, the bank pays income on the fields you own. A high oil price gives a high income and vica verca. A low oil price can turn your income into loss.

The goal of the game is to be the player remaining with any money.

—user summary

In each of the six game modes of Polywords, players must search for the best word to write in their "sea" grids respecting the Constraint card revealed on the table (you will fight with Categories, letters, shapes and a fast sandglass). 
Remember that if you make mistake or if you don't write anything, you will gain a plastic bottle in your sea, which will give negative points at the end of the game: in Polyword, in fact, the winner is the players who has more empty space at the end of the game!

Polywords is a fast party game for 1-6 players in which the shorter words are the key to win!
It contains 6 modes designed for different number of players, 1 solo mode and 2-teams variant!

—description from the designer

Don't play the next urchin ! Here is a party game where you try to survive the next round by not playing a card with an urchin. You can exchange your cards with one of your opponent. You may also try to offer some gifts ton the other players (more cards!) If you are the first play to have no card in your hand, then you win the round!

—description from the publisher

Snakes and Hawks is a card game fun for ages 6 and up and can be played with 2-6 players. Game play is easy and it is very similar to a trick taking card game. Winning the game will take strategy as players will team up with the other players and ultimately using them to their own advantage. While Snakes and Hawks is a team game, there is only one individual winner. You can play 12 unique versions. This is a very thrilling and different card game.
Unlike a normal deck of cards, Snakes and Hawks is played with a 60-card deck. Snakes and Hawks can be played with teams, but unlike other popular trick taking games, your partner doesn’t always have to sit across from you. Your partner can also change every time the cards are dealt. Choosing the right partner could make the difference between winning and losing, The game ends when a player reaches positive 200 or negative 100.

—description from the publisher

In England in 1193, the county of Nottinghamshire suffers under the yoke of evil Prince John and his henchmen. Can Robin Hood and his companions escape the sheriff's guards and complete their adventures successfully?

In The Adventures of Robin Hood, players take on the role of Robin Hood and his companions, with the action taking place on a living game board with no set paths. The board changes over the course of each adventure, and the movement of the characters is handled via an innovative mechanism that uses different length wooden character pieces. Various actions and secrets are integrated into the game levels and are revealed only in the course of the story. The game board "remembers" what players have already explored or found, and thanks to the special materials, the entire game can be set up and dismantled quickly.

Instead of using cards as in the author's Legends of Andor, the game tells the story of Robin Hood in a high-quality hardcover book, and depending on the decisions the players make, the story changes...

Red Banner Northern Fleet explores the Cold War going hot on the high seas. The game is set in 1983, during the last great crisis of the Cold War, occurring before disillusionment with the Soviet system reached critical mass.

The game is inspired by the Avalon classic  Victory in the Pacific. The map depicts the North Atlantic, dividing it into several sea zones. The stats are simplified to facilitate fast game play. However, until Victory in the Pacific, the rules for amphibious landing and land-based aircraft are more involved. Plus the threat of nuclear war hangs over, and if either NATO or the Warsaw Pact does too well, the losing side's government might launch.

—description from the publisher

The Butcher and the Bonnie Prince simulates the last and greatest of the Jacobite uprisings. It uses blocks for units to create fog of war and utilizes an easy combat system. One side plays the Jacobites, which include Scottish Highland and Lowland units as well as English and Welsh. The French will also provide units and could launch a full scale invasion of Britain. The Hanoverians include Scottish Loyalists from the Highlands and Lowlands as well as British regulars and even some Dutch units.

—description from the designer

This is the new edition of Small City, one of the best city-building games that are constructed on a 90° grid, like in real city!

Build Residences, Commerce, and Industries. 
As Mayor, give jobs to your citizens to Produce Raw material, to build Cultural Buildings, and Develop your city - with the long-turn goal to be re-elected at the end of 8 rounds.
Parks, Factories, Tourist agencies, Fire houses and Police Stations are a few of the buildings that can be built, each with a an ability of their own that is added to the game.
As you build up the city, don't forget to take care of the pollution level in order to not ruin your effort...

This new version includes:
- a new revised book of rules
- new illustrations from Kwanchai Moriya!
- new variants that keep the best of the rules of the old edition
- a revised version of the solo game

A quick card game of Wit, War, and Waddle.  Protect your clan of penguins from others and the world at large.  Start by drafting your penguin clan, then spend your turns either adding to your population or destroying others.  The game includes 80 Penguin cards and 20 Event Cards.  Each turn is a simple as drawing a card and playing a card.

The game ends when only one player remains or if the deck runs out of cards, whoever has the strongest penguins is the winner.

Can you navigate a living landmine to become the future ruler of Icetasia?

-description from publisher

This That & Everything: Merry X-Mas Edition is a rapid-fire team based guess game.  The cards include all things Christmas that teams try to guess based on descriptions or clues. Players race to describe a wide variety of holiday related things for their teammates to guess - in 30 seconds or less!

CONTENTS: 100 cards, score pad, 30 second timer and instructions

Make spell cards with the help of the inhabitants of Gensokyo!

Sawagashii Dai-Toshokan is a party-style card game.
The game is based on the idea of "making spell cards for Patchouli" in the Great Library with original gameplay rules.
Players, as fairy maids who usually help Patchouli, have to make spell cards in order not to lose to other maids.
The first maid to make the specified number of spell cards wins the game.

Spell cards can be completed by accumulating attributes belonging to the Five Elements to fulfil their requirements. Fairy maids can seek the help of passers-by, who can lend their abilities, but with so many people within the Great Library, situations may change at any moment, so that the fairy maids must be quick to adapt if they want to show their worth.

Who will be able to impress Patche the most?

You play with three sandtimers of 30 seconds each. Your goal is to coordinate your attacks on the 9 banks of this game. Your opponent may call the Police and you'll spend two rounds of 30 seconds each in jail. This game is quick to understand and you feel the pressure of real gangsters. When four banks are empty, then the players with the more amount of gold and diamonds wins ! Do you want to take risk ? Some banks offers only one gold bar. Others offer much more precious jewels! Surprise!

—description from the publisher

A game the size of a Christmas Card, in which two players race to be the first to put the tree topper on the Christmas tree.

In this game there is no standard turn-order. Instead, the player who is behind will get to roll the die. Ever turn a player is allowed to re-roll the die once, but only the last roll will count.

The trick of this game is not to try and get too much ahead, but instead watch your opponent closely.

—description from the designer

In Ike No Koi, each carp card is presented a number of times equal to its value. You will try to retrieve carp to get the majority in the different carp colors. Be careful not to be too greedy: you reveal two identical cards and the others will help themselves first!

You will be able to win points thanks to your majorities, but also thanks to the power cards, the challenge common to all, and your secret challenge. Don't hesitate to collect carp in the opposing ponds and skilfully protect yourself from trickery to win the game.

Organized crime has overtaken the city. Headquarters wants you and your team to infiltrate the ranks, identify the key players, and break up the syndicate. Do you have what it takes to put a stop to their insidious operations?

In The Feds, players are leaders of FBI units seeking to send agents out to combat crime by arresting criminals. The game is heavily inspired by Gunrunners, an earlier game by the same designer and publisher.

The game is played over a series of rounds. In each round, players simultaneously choose an agent card to play from their hand and a location to play it.  In turn order, players then deploy their agents as moles (face-down) to the chosen locations. If a mole is already at a location, that mole is revealed and is now a "field agent".  Sometimes, when a mole is revealed, a special power will be performed by the owning player of the mole (some agent cards have powers).  These special powers change from game to game for variety of play (based on the City Card being used for the game). They do such things as forcing criminals to move, redeploying agents to new locations, making small arrests, and so on.

At the end of the game, each location is scored and players arrest criminals based on their agent powers at each location.

-description from designer

DESCRIPTION
In the shadow of a living mountain, two warbands clash to see which one will be the hunter and which one will be vanquished. While they make both have come to Beastgrave with different goals in mind, now they simply fight for survival and glory within Direchasm.

Enter the ultimate competitive miniatures game with the Warhammer Underworlds: DIrechasm core set. Inside, you'll find everything you need to start gaming in the depths of the part of Beastgrave known as Direchasm, with dice, models, cards and more.

This set contains:

– The complete rules for Warhammer Underworlds, clearer, sharper and tighter than ever before, featuring thrilling new game mechanics like Primacy, as well as containing lore and art that further explores Beastgrave itself.
– The complete Myari's Purifiers warband – a company of Lumineth aelves seeking to quell the monstrous heart of Beastgrave. Build your warband with the four push fit plastic models, cast in coloured plastic to ensure they stand out even when unpainted, plus fighter cards and a number of warband-specific cards that let you unleash their noble strategies in battle.
– The complete Dread Pageant warband – a group of depraved Hedonites of Slaanesh tormenting the living mountain. Build your warband with the four push fit plastic models, cast in coloured plastic, and build your decks with fighter cards and a number of warband-specific cards that let you harness their power of excess in battle.
– 2 double-sided game boards that can be used to assemble your battlefield.
– Warhammer Underworlds tokens, including objectives, wound markers, glory points and many, many more.
– 32 universal cards – gambits, objectives and upgrades that can be used by any warband, perfect for deck-building with Myari's Purifiers and The Dread Pageant or bringing your favourite warband into Warhammer Underworlds: Direchasm
– 11 Dice – 5 Attack dice, 3 Defence dice and 3 Magic dice, enough for the most devastating blows, desperate defences and cataclysmic spells!

Whether you're a new player looking to start your journey, or a veteran gamer looking to update your game for Season 4, this set is a must-have.

-description from publisher's website

Steady Bayonets 1756 is a set of rules for playing tabletop wargames representing battles in the middle part of the 18th Century, using 15-30mm size model soldiers. The rules cover the period roughly 1740-1790 in Europe.

In these rules, battles are won with lines of well-drilled, bayonet-armed infantry delivering coordinated volleys of musket fire. Cavalry in general cannot take on steady infantry frontally and artillery is not yet powerful enough to be a battle-winning arm.

A typical game has about a dozen units per side. A game like this should take under four hours for a pair of opponents familiar with the rules to complete.

The rules work best with units of 24 infantry models, 12 cavalry models and batteries of 2-4 gun models but this is not a strict requirement.

Game setup usually involves two opposing forces facing one another across a table laid out with terrain models representing hills, woods, streams, etc.

The usual table size is 4-6 feet deep by 6-8 feet across.

Figure and Ground Scales:
• One infantry model = 20 actual men.
• One cavalry model = 20 actual men.
• One cannon model = two actual guns.
• One gunner model = 5 actual crewmen.
• One inch = 20 actual paces (50 feet).

Turn Sequence

     Rally & Command
     Move
     Shoot
     Close combat & Recovery


—description from the publisher

We go back to the time where the landmass of the earth was one. This landmass, called Pangaea is where our story begins.

At the same time, in the far far distance of our Galaxy an earth disaster is heading our way. The famous asteroid that hit the earth over 65 million years ago. When this asteroid hits the earth, the game will end and we will see if the ancestors to mankind where able to survive allowing us humans to rule the planet as we do today.

During the game play, Pangaea will change, continents will rise and fall, opportunities to survive will come and go, are you lucky enough? Are you strategic enough?

Dinosaurs will make your changes to survive more difficult and volcano eruptions can happen any time, covering everything in lava.

Earthquakes and Tsunamis are mother nature’s forces that will challenge you. Are you able to outsmart your fellow players? It´s survival of mankind but it better be your offspring to rule the world, or perhaps nobody shall survive!?

This game is a typical hex-tile and worker placement. Tiles will also be stacked/unstacked on the board during the game.

Each player starts with 4 cards at hand, visible to all. 
From the 4 cards you select 2 (or 3 for experience gamers) to represent in order: 

     a number of tiles displacement of the event-locator, 
     an action that will take place at that new location and 
     (optional, based on chosen game play) the range, i.e. number of tiles, that is affected by that action. 


Played cards are discarded and new cards are added to the players hand for a next round.

The event-locator, positioned on the board, points out where the action as given by the card will take place. Possible actions are land-rise, land-fall, climate change, earthquake/tsunami or dinosaur placement. Depending on the game-type, more than 1 tile can be affected.

Each players meeple walks around the continents to harvest points or to place shelters (up to 3) but they are continuously in danger due to the effects of the actions that can happen to the continent (or tile) the players meeple and shelters are on. As player, you can chose to work with your fellow players or work against them, finding an alliance or break it again.

Not all land-types can support players meeples or dinosaurs, but you can buy evolution cards that can give you a bit of help, but it will cost you points.

Not all land-types are suitable for shelter building either or you shall choose between scoring points and harvest or not to harvest and move to a better spot to be able, in your next turn, to finally build your shelter. Can you build and keep your shelters on the board and earn the most points along the way? Shelters that you can keep on the board start earning points for you as well.

Only if at least 1 of your shelters survives the end game when the famous asteroid impacts the earth, then and only then will you have a change to win the game. During the game-play the asteroid is triggered and will move closer to earth from the starting place you have chosen. This determines (more or less) the game length. The speed in which it approaches is different each game, making it hard to predict how much time or turns is still left in the game. But when the asteroid reaches the earth, the end game begins.

Simply stated, ensure your ancestors survive the impact and earn the most points during the game, that will make you the winner.

—description from the designer

Top Tale: Tall Tale is a spin off of Top Tale: The Original Game (O.G.), where the twist is that for each topic a fantastical element must be added into the players' responses. Similar to The O.G. series, the game can be played with 2-10 players, ages 10+, and a typical game lasts 30+ minutes, taking less than two minutes to learn.

In Top Tale: Tall Tale, players will still get to know each other, however the stories aren't expected to be based solely on the truth. The stories are expected to be exaggerated and unbelievable, which makes the best story often times the most entertaining story.

Top Tale: Tall Tale can be integrated with other Top Tale volumes during gameplay, where the Tall Tale cards are clearly marked to cue players to stretch the truth. The other game play mechanics are all the same as the rest of the Top Tale series.

-description from publisher

Amaze your family and friends with your knowledge about all eight movies, from Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone to Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2.

Your Hogwarts house determines which questions you will answer, so begin the game by declaring whether you are Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw, Slytherin, or Gryffindor.

Spin the spinner and take the corresponding movie card. The player to your left reads aloud the question for your Hogwarts house and you have one minute to answer.

Correctly answer a card to keep it. If the spinner lands on a movie you’ve already won, you must still answer the question to get an extra spin. Collect a card from each movie to win.

Each of the 1600 question cards also displays the answer along with a short explanation about the topic. The aim is to be the first to collect a full set of 8 movie cards.

Can you escape in time?

You have 60 minutes to solve the puzzles!

A mad scientist has sent a weapon capable of destroying entire cities into orbit. Trapped in the computer room of an underground base, you must find the code that will deactivate the dangerous satellite.

The countdown has started: the gun will fire in 60 minutes ...

This escape box contains:
. 1 32-page booklet with the rules of the game, the scenario and the solutions.
. 40 cards to hide everywhere.
. 1 60-minute soundtrack.
. 1 poster.

Pays de Guérande et Saint-Nazaire is an original, local and user-friendly board game based on the principle of questions and answers.

Nearly 550 written questions and photos with also charades and riddles, "junior" questions which deal with subjects as varied as history or geography going from Guérande to Saint-Etienne-de-Montluc via Pontchateau, the Sillon de Bretagne, heritage, local traditions, current events or famous people who have marked the territory of Guérande, Saint-Nazaire...

The aim of the game is to gain as many French regions as possible by answering questions.

The board is comprised of bottom side serving as a wheel indicator, and a top side representing the map of France in the shape of a hexagon.

On each turn, the player turns the HEXAGON board and rolls the dice; the number indicates on the board either a region, a Chance card, or a Question card.

On a "Region" space, the player wins it if he correctly gives his name; he then scores as many points as the number on the dice. He gains additional points if he gives the capital, the departments.

On the "Chance" boxes the player can gain or lose points then play again, can play with the islands (Corsica, DOM) and gain points in the same way as on a "Region" box.

On the "Questions" boxes, the player answers as many questions as there are points achieved by rolling the dice; each correct answer is worth as many points as those of the dice. Certain boxes allow the points obtained to be multiplied by 2. In addition, the possession of all departments of a region earns bonus points, as well as possession of regions of the same color.

The best total wins the game.

2000 questions for the transition to the 2000 year.
18000 classic questions on Belgium (geography, history, sciences, politics, gastronomy, sports, various facts, folklore, culture) and 200 infernal questions.

—description from the back of the box (translated)
